This game takes what worked from other survival titles such as Ark: Survival Evolved, Conan Exiles, and The Forest and mixes them together. I don’t like calling it “Pokémon with guns,” because the game doesn’t follow a JRPG-style linear story. Instead, it’s a free-roam survival experience, despite the similar art style and creature-capture mechanics (which have been around far longer than Pokémon).

The controls are well done, and the creature progression feels fair. No Pal goes forgotten—there is always a use for each one, no matter your progression. You never feel obligated to abandon your little penguin Pal just because you’ve moved on to stronger creatures.

The world feels alive, with pockets of NPCs to visit, both friendly and… not so friendly. This helps solve the “empty hostile world” problem that many survival games struggle with. When you visit a town, you’ll see NPCs performing small tasks that make them feel less like interactive cardboard cutouts and more like background characters living their own lives. Another nice touch is the visits from random merchants, which can genuinely help the player along. It’s much better than finding a “traveling merchant” standing in the same spot on the map every time. Some of the dialogue still feels a little stilted, but honestly? We’re not here for deep engagement with NPCs we’re here for the gameplay loop.

It’s hard to review Palworld without mentioning the lawsuit by Game Freak/Nintendo. Personally, I feel the lawsuit was in poor taste, especially as it has shifted into a larger company attempting to patent things like riding an animal something humanity has been doing throughout history. Regardless, if you go into Palworld without the “Pokémon with guns” mindset, you’ll find a much more rewarding experience.

Palworld is stupid fun in the best way. It looks cute at first, then suddenly you’re crafting guns, catching creatures, building factories, and letting those same adorable creatures run your entire operation like overworked employees. The loop is addictive: explore, catch, build, upgrade, repeat.

Yeah, it’s chaotic and a bit janky at times, but honestly that’s part of the charm. Watching a tiny smiling Pal operate heavy machinery or fire a rifle never stops being entertaining. Solo or with friends, it’s one of those games where an hour turns into five without noticing.

If you want something serious and polished, skip it. If you just want to have fun, break things, and create questionable ethical decisions with cute animal-workers, this game nails it.

For an Open World Survival Crafter Creature Collector, which in on itself is a mouthful, Palworld is quite a good game. Battling with & against Pals of different level, size and stats as well as different attacks keeps the game interesting and entertaining. Finding NPCs with Pals to fight against is also interesting, just like fighting trainers in Pokémon. The world also feels more alive thanks to the recent updates to the game, so it's not like you're going over large distances of nothingness. Of course, having a large world that isn't completely empty does raise another problem: inventory management.

Palworld operates with a limited inventory space that can be upgraded when progressing through the game, as well as a carry weight limit, which also can be increased. But having both limited inventory and a limit to how much weight one can carry does mean that one cannot carry too much of heavy stuff like metal, stone or wood, which are important materials for crafting items & base buildings, and it also limits how much different items one can have in their inventory at a time, which does include not only materials, but money, food and consumables, as well as Pal spheres. And while one can upgrade their carry limit and inventory space, it does require some rare materials for both. And that is another thing I personally find quite a bother.

As a Survival Crafter game, there's obviously a lot of materials one can obtain which are used for different things. Some materials are very common, like wood or stone, where other materials are less common, like high-quality pal oil. There are even some very rare materials that can only be obtained from specific sources, either a certain location or from certain types or species of Pals. Some crafting recipes are also very material-hungry, which does lead to material grinding which is quite bothersome. As mentioned before, there's metal which can be mined, but it is not the only "ore" to exist in the game. And like metal ore, all of the "ores" are pretty heavy and you will need a lot of ore to process to make higher-leveled equipment, make better base buildings and to repair the higher-leveled equipment. The whole progress becomes more time-consuming the further you progress in the game, and the game expects the player to just deal with it. Unless someone has found a way to make the progress less bothersome, it's going to be a pain later in the game progression.

Now, there are a lot of Pals in the game, some look cool, some don't, and many remind players of Pokémon, and Pals also have different types just like Pokémon, which means that some types do more damage to other types while doing less damage to other types. However, almost every type has only one strength and two weaknesses where one is that the attack does less damage to the Pal of the same type, with fire element doing more damage and taking less damage against Grass and Ice element, and normal element having no type it does extra damage to. This simple type effectiveness chart means that against bosses you practically need the full party of 5 Pals to be of a specific type to do more damage against the boss and to survive against the boss for longer. Now that might not sound too bad to some players but I personally like some Pals more than others and would rather play Palworld with the same mindset as with Pokémon games, where I use my favorite Pokémon to play through the game. It is a shame though, that many of my favorite Pals are Dark element.

Still, even after the few things that I personally find as bothersome, the game is fun and entertaining for the most part, and some of the Pals have some cool design and interesting abilities, from Pals you use to travel on land, in water or in the air to Pals that use guns to fight alongside you. And to me, being able to build a house with Japanese aesthetics is like a cherry on top.

Though, I still haven't played with other people so I should try to do that at some point.

Palworld is a creature-collection survival game that mixes open-world exploration, base building, and combat with a darkly comedic tone. At its core, the loop revolves around capturing Pals, assembling a team suited for gathering, crafting, and fighting, and steadily expanding your operations across a large, resource-rich map. The blend of survival mechanics with monster-raising creates a structure that is familiar but distinct from traditional creature-collecting games.

Pals serve dual roles as companions and labor. Each species excels at different tasks, so efficient base management depends on assigning the right Pal to jobs such as farming, refining, mining, or guarding. Watching bases operate autonomously is a major part of the appeal, and upgrading facilities turns your settlement into a self-sustaining production chain. The automation system provides clear progression without excessive micromanagement.

Combat is built around third-person shooting, melee attacks, and Pal abilities. Different Pals offer elemental powers, burst damage, or utility skills, encouraging experimentation with team compositions. Boss encounters found across the world act as difficulty spikes and offer valuable rewards. While the combat is accessible, certain encounters require preparation, proper gear, and tactical use of your Pals to succeed.

Exploration is broad and flexible. Biomes range from forests and deserts to snowy mountains and volcanic regions, each populated with unique Pals and resources. The variety of traversal tools—mounts, gliders, and specialized Pals—helps reduce travel time and opens new ways to navigate the environment. Discovering new zones, dungeons, and landmarks ties progression directly to exploration.

The game’s tone is intentionally absurd, contrasting cute creature designs with mechanics that allow for weapon crafting, base defense, and industrial automation. This juxtaposition is part of its identity, though some players may find the darker humor or morally ambiguous systems off-putting. Regardless, the presentation stays consistent and leans into its own eccentricity.

Multiplayer expands the experience by enabling cooperative base building and exploration. Coordinated teams can tackle tougher bosses, create shared production lines, and progress more efficiently. Performance can vary depending on server setup, but the cooperative structure adds replay value and long-term engagement.

Palworld succeeds by merging survival crafting, automated labor systems, and creature collection into a single loop that rewards exploration and experimentation. Its unconventional tone and flexible mechanics make it stand out within the genre, appealing to players who enjoy open-world progression driven by both personal skill and an evolving roster of creatures.

At first, I thought Palworld was skating too close to Pokémon’s shadow... but after playing it, I realized it’s not a copy at all — it’s a clever rebellion against predictable game design. When major publishers are busy patenting every small mechanic, Palworld feels like a breath of freedom for players who crave creativity and risk-taking.

What makes this game shine is how it transforms familiar ideas into something truly new. It’s not just “Pokémon with guns”... it’s an open-world survival adventure where exploration, automation, crafting, and creature companionship all blend together perfectly. Your Pals aren’t just for combat; they live with you — farming, mining, building, and fighting with genuine personality and charm.

Exploring the world is deeply rewarding. Each biome feels distinct... forests, snowy peaks, and deserts full of secrets and unique Pals to discover. The sense of progression is strong too — building your base from a small camp into a thriving automated settlement is surprisingly addictive. The tech tree, crafting, and automation systems give you endless goals to chase.

Combat is fun and chaotic, with both melee and ranged options. It’s darkly funny at times — seeing your cute Pals wield firearms shouldn’t work, but somehow it fits perfectly. After a lot of play, I can’t recommend this game. It isn’t outright terrible, but the sheer number of bugs and balance problems hold it back from being what it could be.

PAL abilities are often costly but useless, and PALs swap setups whenever they level. Passive bonuses are far too random, frequently rolling on PALs that can’t even use them. Some PALs feel like they had no effort put into their design at all, while others are very well made, which makes the inconsistency stand out even more. Player gear durability also drains far too quickly, adding another layer of frustration to progression.

The AI is a mess. PALs in the base sometimes get stuck and starve for unknown reasons, repeat pointless actions, swap tasks without reason, and at times refuse to engage because they endlessly spam the dodge move instead of fighting. They sometimes stay locked on distant foes instead of the ones right next to them, wasting time and leaving you exposed. Defensive abilities are used with no purpose, sometimes even to initiate combat against non‑alerted or non‑hostile PALs.

Leveling up itself isn’t too bad, but overall progression can’t keep pace, and while new areas may look different, they rarely add anything fresh to the gameplay beyond appearances. Finding new PALs can be exciting, but there aren’t enough stats exposed to the player to understand what differences swapping around actually makes. It becomes hard to know the optimal path forward, and eventually you’re forced into leveling new PALs just to keep up. With limited storage and only five PAL team slots to use when out and about, this quickly becomes a nightmare. PALs barely gain experience while working in base, so you have to bring them with you to level, or use consumable items that can be farmed very slowly — but doing this for dozens or even hundreds of PALs is not viable. Re‑catching them instead feels dumb and highlights the gaps in game design. This is more tedious than fun.

At higher levels, progression becomes extremely frustrating. You may reach higher levels, but you can’t get what you need because resources stop keeping pace with player effort. The game seems designed around the expectation of having more allies, yet there’s no option to compensate for solo play. Gathering certain resources requires many hands, and PALs simply can’t keep up, making late‑game play a slog.

Base building isn’t the worst, but it is heavily restricted with odd space requirements and strange placement limitations. Resource gathering is uneven. Some low‑tier resources are harder to get than they should be, yet you need far more of them than is reasonable, and not all can be auto‑gathered by PALs. Inventory management is another chore: too many items, no auto‑deposit features, and the need for hundreds of chests just to store everything. Like in many other games, there’s no thought given to where the abundance of items introduced should actually go. I don’t understand why there need to be so many items without at least allowing conversion or consolidation.

Playing with a few people on a dedicated server might improve the experience, but solo play feels stagnant even after a year’s break. New PAL introductions don’t help when balance and functionality remain broken.

There’s potential here, but polish is sorely lacking. I know this is early access, yet the game has been around for a long time already, and most titles don’t change much between early access and release. I doubt there will be meaningful improvement, though I suppose time will tell.

My thumbs down isn’t because the game is unplayable — it can be fun for a while. But the mountain of issues builds frustration until the fun is gone. Worse, you end up playing more simply because the time you’ve already invested makes you reluctant to abandon progress. That’s why I can’t give it a thumbs up. In the end, it’s a frustrating mess of a game as it stands.

I want to leave a review here hoping that Palworld devs will see it and address my complaints. I would also like to add a disclaimer that Palworld is by no means a bad game; it is very fun and by all rights deserves all of the positive reviews it receives.

Why, then, am I leaving this negative review? Well, it's because Palworld is a negative experience specifically for me. I started playing the game in early access, and ultimately I never managed to get very far because my favorite aspect of the game--base building--is very broken, flawed, and inconvenient.

I'm going to start with the most severe flaw, in my opinion. The basics are all there and decent, but the problems arise when evaluated in combination with other systems. Specifically, pathing for Pals. Pals simply do not understand how to navigate bases, and this puts severe restrictions on a player's ability to creatively design the exact kind of base that they want to have because it comes into competition with practicality. Want a cliff base? Well, be ready for most of your Pals not to be able to access much of your base due to their inability to path to different floors of a base. Even a base that is on a cliff that extends down to the base of the cliff faces problems because unless there is a natural (not player-placed) path between the levels, the pals get stuck

I think I figured out the problem and it's simply that pals only really recognize terrain that isn't player created. Sure, they can stand on and in some capacity interact with player-built platforms and stairs, but for all intents and purposes they do not see them as viable paths for getting from one place to another. This essentially means that the only practical way of building a base is on perfectly flat terrain, and that sucks.

My second complaint is more of a quality of life one--would it be too much to ask for a streamlined and simplified method of replacing existing walls and floors with the upgraded tier of them? Maybe this already exists in the game as some sort of upgrade that I never managed to reach, but I don't think so. Please, just let us overlap old floors with new ones and place the new ones. Ideally we would reclaim the old resources, but honestly I don't even care if we did. The problem with the system not being this way already is when it comes to needing to replace foundation/"load-bearing" platforms or anything with crafting interfaces on top of them; you have to manually destroy and rebuild absolutely everything. When combined with the fact that (as I mentioned in my last complaint) pals can't always reach places in your base if it is comprised of different levels, and this becomes a very time-consuming and annoying process.

Basically, the base-building needs better integration with the Pal pathing and better optimization and quality-of-life injected into it. I hate to leave a negative review over these very specific and isolated issues, but the fact is that base-building is a very major part of the game and one of the parts that would otherwise have been my favorite thing to engage with. When I played the game over a year ago in early access I had hoped that these issues would just naturally get resolved in a series of patches, but after having returned to the game and none of these issues having been addressed it left me with concerns. Genuinely, and not hyperbolizing here, it kills my desire to play the game. I've owned this game for over a year, I WANT to love this game (and genuinely do love a lot of it), but my playtime is a testament to the fact that it's just impossible for me, personally, to get over these problems.

I know the lawsuits with Nintendo have likely taken a lot of time and attention away from what could have been used improving the game, so I hope that anyone reading this takes this review with a grain of salt, especially the developers. I'm leaving it because these problems do affect my enjoyment enough to ruin the game for me (which to me warrants a subjectively placed negative review) and because I know that negative reviews often receive attention better than buried forum posts do. I'll definitely update my review if major improvements are ever implemented into the base-building aspects of the game.

Game starts fine, you get to next techs pretty fast but then you discover areas with higher level brackets and get completely stomped by aggressive spawns and little to no fast travel points. And then the need to grind hits you. At first, it can and should be automated, only requiring manual intervention once in a while to gather small amounts of non-automatable resources. Automation itself is a bit of a pain because buildings that produce resources suck at first and you have to find one of the like 3 locations with good amount of natural deposits. Then you unlock 3rd tier of material and it requires resource that can't be automated up until you basically get to the next tier. This material also allows to make actual guns and they suck! Every bullet is made using manual labor to gather 2 different resources and 3-step process to make just a bit of ammo painfully slowly. To unlock full ammo automation you basically have to finish the game, or at least, what was originally the game. For a "Pokemon with guns" the gun part is too expensive. Then one of the "endgame" materials has a straight-up non-automatable component. This also appears to be the theme of expansions, new resources require you to either run around vast and mostly empty locations, avoiding unneccessary fights as they slow you down, and gathering required resources, or sit on the base and breed and butcher ONE species of pal. Good thing relevant ammo can be automated, right? Nope, there's only grind in the endgame. I played until level 47 and got tired of doing the same dungeons to gather just a bit of resources.

Venting is mostly over, now for the review part. 

Graphics are okay-ish, you find visibly stretched terrain textures basically everywhere outside of roads. 

Sound exists and works, no complaints here.

Optimization is inconsistent. Open world with baked lighting works fine but as soon as dynamic lighting gets involved, things get laggy. Don't even try to illuminate the room you frequently visit unless you want as frequent FPS drops, use natural lighting instead. Otherwise, the game runs fine even when using AoE attacks on large groups of enemies.

Pal designs are decent, older ones are "reimagined" Pokemon designs and there're like 2 pal designs I genuinlny like, newer ones are better but I haven't seen them much due to new locations being behind grind walls. 

Human enemies are pointless, feel the same and the only lore behind them are 100+ damn notes that i'm not going to collect, we're not in Slenderman. Human interactable NPCs exist but usually for single function, be it a single quest, a trickle of free resources, a pointless phrase, or a shop.

Location difficulties vary wildly, you can have "starting" zone border engame death forest with the same pals, just 40 (out of 60 total) levels higher. Same goes for occasional NPC bases, how about a random endgame base where you'd get oneshot situated in the middle of second level bracket zone?

Base building is bad. There might be a bunch of decorations but you can't make a non-prismatic structure at all, there aren't even corner roof pieces! Building restrictions are inconsistent, you might be able to place structures one way, but not vice versa. Doors straight up suck. Moving with grappling hook is faster anyway and doors only obstruct your path...

Pal automation is underwhelming. Job priority is non-sensical, they switch between tasks uncontrollably, bug out during pathfinding, only eat until they have 50% of satiety when they hit <50% statiety and if you use cheap food - too bad, they will go eating every 30 seconds until you install a mod to fix it or switch to a more grindy food that expires quickly by the way. Full automation is impossible because you can't automate task creation or even do it remotely.

Survival aspect is basically non-existent, it's actualy hard to find yourself in a forced death situation in the open world once you get your mobility options a few hours into the game. NPC base assaults are a slog, half of the enemy attacks ignore walls, your pals have a non-zero chance to get stuck and die inside the cramped buildings. Non-"raid" bosses are huge damage sponges with a time limit. I don't know how AI chooses targets but they usually focus me, and if they focus my pal - it dies in under a minute. Haven't tried "raid" bosses but those have even higher hp and are supposed to be killed using your base defences.

Exploration part is mostly fine, until you get to mountain zones. Most locations are empty outside of a few trees, rocks and the same copy-paste minor vegetations but mountains are even emptier, having fewer rewards and a wall on the side of your screen. Sometimes distant islands show up as unshaded PNGs intead of foggy shaded ones, scaring you in the dark by, for example, a bunch of bright ice.

Pal combat AI sucks, they can start attacking unreachable enemies, ignoring ones right in front of them and using the command menu requires you to stand in place for several seconds, while there are a dozen of projectiles aimed straight in your face.

Endgame balance is something I don't understand. You're supposed to breed your pals to pass down passives you want but I haven't tried it, instead using the ones I caught and proceed to lose my pals every time they get focused (compared to early game when they can tank for you). You can't predict damage attack can deal based on "power" alone, sometimes this includes collision shenanigans. It seems "power" only shows damage potential of a single damage tick and amount of those can vary between 1 and BEAM(several tens). Beams are just heavens above anything else, especially if used by you while riding your pal because they can actually be aimed during attack animation, unlike when AI uses them. Also endgame NPC bases can have several beam users inside at once so if you lag for a few seconds your pal dies. The concept of "higher damage - longer cooldown" sucks. You are forced to juggle your pals for consistent damage output since endgame skills have cooldowns of about a minute.

Overall, a decent grinding game but progression slows down significantly as you approach endgame. I don't think it's worth the money or the time you spend doing dungeons to craft another 5 magazines for your assault rifle.

Honestly, the only thing that really irks me about this game is seeing how much progress has been made - and yet, some very basic and fundamental game mechanics have been disregarded for so long that I wouldn't recommend it. Now, hear me out please before the insane stans bombard me with clown awards. Palworld is fun. It's a good game. But the atrocious AI, god awful pathing and navmesh issues, and crazy clipping bugs will have you tearing your hair out. Especially towards the end game content. 

For example, I tend to play everything on very difficult settings. Often with permadeath. It isn't even fathomable to try with Palworld. Your pal will frequently run straight by enemies in order to chase down some random ass guy who somehow, despite being on the complete opposite side of the POI and stuck running into a wall, has drawn aggro. They will prioritize aggro'd units and there is currently no way to command or micromanage your pals. If they can even go chase them down. More likely they'll get caught on a corner or some stairs or just flat out be summoned and then not move. Because that's how fucked the pathing and AI is. And since it's end game content, maybe that random ass guy will summon a little tocotoco bird who will, through multiple floors and walls, hyper beam your ass into oblivion. And sure, you can often easily cheese content as well, blasting people through walls and rooftops with aoe skills. But that isn't fun or challenging. It's tedious, and there is only so much dopamine to be had by watching numbers go up.

And so the novelty of exploring quickly wears off when you realize the chests, the eggs, they're just filler. It's a landscape filled with distraction more than anything. And so the immersion wears off and the zip from point A to B begins. And then the novelty of your pals wears off as you realize, your choices are pretty moot. There's a bit of preference and then there's the end game pals which you can easily get to with the first chicken and lamb that you pick up. And you'll just need them to keep doing end game content. Or, you turn the difficulty up and spend days if not weeks breeding, not because you enjoy making the numbers go up at this point but because you need too. And there's no novelty to be had with achieving the next tier of gear either, since the game rushes you through the first ~40 levels (out of 60). You'll basically be starting at metal/refined metal and it doesn't change after that.

My point is, the longevity of the game is entirely forced and artificial at this point. The balance isn't there. It's exciting and easily hooks you in the beginning because at it's core concept, Palworld is a very fun and addicting game. And if you decide to buy it I'm sure you will have fun and mostly have a net gain on the entertainment/frustration scale. But it is alarming to me that the most basic game mechanics have not been improved in nearly 2 years since it's release to EA. It is frustrating that due to the lawsuit, a huge piece of the game was hamstringed, but even more so that they haven't done ANYTHING to replace it. 

Oh and also, mandatory aim assist? What the fuck. You know how many pokespheres got wasted due to this trash snapping onto a moving target instead of being able to lead? 

But that's all. I'm tired of the jank. I just want to enjoy the game fully with out being laser beamed through two walls and a cargo container just to watch helplessly as my oatmeal thicc character gets pushed into a column and grabs on to climb, repeatedly, stun locking me until death. Please focus on the basic game play mechanics and polish for once. My Anubis has been stuck on the stairs for DAYS.
Focus less on crossovers with other games and more on making your own game more fleshed out.

After a lot of play, I can’t recommend this game. It isn’t outright terrible, but the sheer number of bugs and balance problems hold it back from being what it could be.

PAL abilities are often costly but useless, and PALs swap setups whenever they level. Passive bonuses are far too random, frequently rolling on PALs that can’t even use them. Some PALs feel like they had no effort put into their design at all, while others are very well made, which makes the inconsistency stand out even more. Player gear durability also drains far too quickly, adding another layer of frustration to progression.

The AI is a mess. PALs in the base sometimes get stuck and starve for unknown reasons, repeat pointless actions, swap tasks without reason, and at times refuse to engage because they endlessly spam the dodge move instead of fighting. They sometimes stay locked on distant foes instead of the ones right next to them, wasting time and leaving you exposed. Defensive abilities are used with no purpose, sometimes even to initiate combat against non‑alerted or non‑hostile PALs.

Leveling up itself isn’t too bad, but overall progression can’t keep pace, and while new areas may look different, they rarely add anything fresh to the gameplay beyond appearances. Finding new PALs can be exciting, but there aren’t enough stats exposed to the player to understand what differences swapping around actually makes. It becomes hard to know the optimal path forward, and eventually you’re forced into leveling new PALs just to keep up. With limited storage and only five PAL team slots to use when out and about, this quickly becomes a nightmare. PALs barely gain experience while working in base, so you have to bring them with you to level, or use consumable items that can be farmed very slowly — but doing this for dozens or even hundreds of PALs is not viable. Re‑catching them instead feels dumb and highlights the gaps in game design. This is more tedious than fun.

At higher levels, progression becomes extremely frustrating. You may reach higher levels, but you can’t get what you need because resources stop keeping pace with player effort. The game seems designed around the expectation of having more allies, yet there’s no option to compensate for solo play. Gathering certain resources requires many hands, and PALs simply can’t keep up, making late‑game play a slog.

Base building isn’t the worst, but it is heavily restricted with odd space requirements and strange placement limitations. Resource gathering is uneven. Some low‑tier resources are harder to get than they should be, yet you need far more of them than is reasonable, and not all can be auto‑gathered by PALs. Inventory management is another chore: too many items, no auto‑deposit features, and the need for hundreds of chests just to store everything. Like in many other games, there’s no thought given to where the abundance of items introduced should actually go. I don’t understand why there need to be so many items without at least allowing conversion or consolidation.

Playing with a few people on a dedicated server might improve the experience, but solo play feels stagnant even after a year’s break. New PAL introductions don’t help when balance and functionality remain broken.

There’s potential here, but polish is sorely lacking. I know this is early access, yet the game has been around for a long time already, and most titles don’t change much between early access and release. I doubt there will be meaningful improvement, though I suppose time will tell.

My thumbs down isn’t because the game is unplayable — it can be fun for a while. But the mountain of issues builds frustration until the fun is gone. Worse, you end up playing more simply because the time you’ve already invested makes you reluctant to abandon progress. That’s why I can’t give it a thumbs up. In the end, it’s a frustrating mess of a game as it stands.

I want to leave a review here hoping that Palworld devs will see it and address my complaints. I would also like to add a disclaimer that Palworld is by no means a bad game; it is very fun and by all rights deserves all of the positive reviews it receives.

Why, then, am I leaving this negative review? Well, it's because Palworld is a negative experience specifically for me. I started playing the game in early access, and ultimately I never managed to get very far because my favorite aspect of the game--base building--is very broken, flawed, and inconvenient.

I'm going to start with the most severe flaw, in my opinion. The basics are all there and decent, but the problems arise when evaluated in combination with other systems. Specifically, pathing for Pals. Pals simply do not understand how to navigate bases, and this puts severe restrictions on a player's ability to creatively design the exact kind of base that they want to have because it comes into competition with practicality. Want a cliff base? Well, be ready for most of your Pals not to be able to access much of your base due to their inability to path to different floors of a base. Even a base that is on a cliff that extends down to the base of the cliff faces problems because unless there is a natural (not player-placed) path between the levels, the pals get stuck

I think I figured out the problem and it's simply that pals only really recognize terrain that isn't player created. Sure, they can stand on and in some capacity interact with player-built platforms and stairs, but for all intents and purposes they do not see them as viable paths for getting from one place to another. This essentially means that the only practical way of building a base is on perfectly flat terrain, and that sucks.

My second complaint is more of a quality of life one--would it be too much to ask for a streamlined and simplified method of replacing existing walls and floors with the upgraded tier of them? Maybe this already exists in the game as some sort of upgrade that I never managed to reach, but I don't think so. Please, just let us overlap old floors with new ones and place the new ones. Ideally we would reclaim the old resources, but honestly I don't even care if we did. The problem with the system not being this way already is when it comes to needing to replace foundation/"load-bearing" platforms or anything with crafting interfaces on top of them; you have to manually destroy and rebuild absolutely everything. When combined with the fact that (as I mentioned in my last complaint) pals can't always reach places in your base if it is comprised of different levels, and this becomes a very time-consuming and annoying process.

Basically, the base-building needs better integration with the Pal pathing and better optimization and quality-of-life injected into it. I hate to leave a negative review over these very specific and isolated issues, but the fact is that base-building is a very major part of the game and one of the parts that would otherwise have been my favorite thing to engage with. When I played the game over a year ago in early access I had hoped that these issues would just naturally get resolved in a series of patches, but after having returned to the game and none of these issues having been addressed it left me with concerns. Genuinely, and not hyperbolizing here, it kills my desire to play the game. I've owned this game for over a year, I WANT to love this game (and genuinely do love a lot of it), but my playtime is a testament to the fact that it's just impossible for me, personally, to get over these problems.

I know the lawsuits with Nintendo have likely taken a lot of time and attention away from what could have been used improving the game, so I hope that anyone reading this takes this review with a grain of salt, especially the developers. I'm leaving it because these problems do affect my enjoyment enough to ruin the game for me (which to me warrants a subjectively placed negative review) and because I know that negative reviews often receive attention better than buried forum posts do. I'll definitely update my review if major improvements are ever implemented into the base-building aspects of the game.

Every bullet is made using manual labor to gather 2 different resources and 3-step process to make just a bit of ammo painfully slowly. To unlock full ammo automation you basically have to finish the game, or at least, what was originally the game. For a "Pokemon with guns" the gun part is too expensive. Then one of the "endgame" materials has a straight-up non-automatable component. This also appears to be the theme of expansions, new resources require you to either run around vast and mostly empty locations, avoiding unneccessary fights as they slow you down, and gathering required resources, or sit on the base and breed and butcher ONE species of pal. Good thing relevant ammo can be automated, right? Nope, there's only grind in the endgame. I played until level 47 and got tired of doing the same dungeons to gather just a bit of resources.

Venting is mostly over, now for the review part. 

Graphics are okay-ish, you find visibly stretched terrain textures basically everywhere outside of roads. 

Sound exists and works, no complaints here.

Optimization is inconsistent. Open world with baked lighting works fine but as soon as dynamic lighting gets involved, things get laggy. Don't even try to illuminate the room you frequently visit unless you want as frequent FPS drops, use natural lighting instead. Otherwise, the game runs fine even when using AoE attacks on large groups of enemies.

Pal designs are decent, older ones are "reimagined" Pokemon designs and there're like 2 pal designs I genuinlny like, newer ones are better but I haven't seen them much due to new locations being behind grind walls. 

Human enemies are pointless, feel the same and the only lore behind them are 100+ damn notes that i'm not going to collect, we're not in Slenderman. Human interactable NPCs exist but usually for single function, be it a single quest, a trickle of free resources, a pointless phrase, or a shop.

Location difficulties vary wildly, you can have "starting" zone border engame death forest with the same pals, just 40 (out of 60 total) levels higher. Same goes for occasional NPC bases, how about a random endgame base where you'd get oneshot situated in the middle of second level bracket zone?

Base building is bad. There might be a bunch of decorations but you can't make a non-prismatic structure at all, there aren't even corner roof pieces! Building restrictions are inconsistent, you might be able to place structures one way, but not vice versa. Doors straight up suck. Moving with grappling hook is faster anyway and doors only obstruct your path...

Pal automation is underwhelming. Job priority is non-sensical, they switch between tasks uncontrollably, bug out during pathfinding, only eat until they have 50% of satiety when they hit <50% statiety and if you use cheap food - too bad, they will go eating every 30 seconds until you install a mod to fix it or switch to a more grindy food that expires quickly by the way. Full automation is impossible because you can't automate task creation or even do it remotely.

Survival aspect is basically non-existent, it's actualy hard to find yourself in a forced death situation in the open world once you get your mobility options a few hours into the game. NPC base assaults are a slog, half of the enemy attacks ignore walls, your pals have a non-zero chance to get stuck and die inside the cramped buildings. Non-"raid" bosses are huge damage sponges with a time limit. I don't know how AI chooses targets but they usually focus me, and if they focus my pal - it dies in under a minute. Haven't tried "raid" bosses but those have even higher hp and are supposed to be killed using your base defences.

Exploration part is mostly fine, until you get to mountain zones. Most locations are empty outside of a few trees, rocks and the same copy-paste minor vegetations but mountains are even emptier, having fewer rewards and a wall on the side of your screen. Sometimes distant islands show up as unshaded PNGs intead of foggy shaded ones, scaring you in the dark by, for example, a bunch of bright ice.

Pal combat AI sucks, they can start attacking unreachable enemies, ignoring ones right in front of them and using the command menu requires you to stand in place for several seconds, while there are a dozen of projectiles aimed straight in your face.

Endgame balance is something I don't understand. You're supposed to breed your pals to pass down passives you want but I haven't tried it, instead using the ones I caught and proceed to lose my pals every time they get focused (compared to early game when they can tank for you). You can't predict damage attack can deal based on "power" alone, sometimes this includes collision shenanigans. It seems "power" only shows damage potential of a single damage tick and amount of those can vary between 1 and BEAM(several tens). Beams are just heavens above anything else, especially if used by you while riding your pal because they can actually be aimed during attack animation, unlike when AI uses them. Also endgame NPC bases can have several beam users inside at once so if you lag for a few seconds your pal dies. The concept of "higher damage - longer cooldown" sucks. You are forced to juggle your pals for consistent damage output since endgame skills have cooldowns of about a minute.

Overall, a decent grinding game but progression slows down significantly as you approach endgame. I don't think it's worth the money or the time you spend doing dungeons to craft another 5 magazines for your assault rifle.
